questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A mutation of tRNA can suppress the effect of a stop codon, allowing protein synthesis to continue and leading to the reversal of the mutant phenotype to the wild type.
  • ➤ mutation of tRNA

questions.text: As shown in Image, is due to deficiency of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Zinc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency leads to acrodermatitis enteropathica , which is characterized by peri-orificial and acral dermatitis, along with diarrhea due to impaired zinc absorption.
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency
  • ➤ acrodermatitis enteropathica

questions.text: After a meal, blood glucose enters cells and is stored as glycogen, particularly in the liver. Which of the following is the donor of new glucose molecules in glycogen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) UDP-glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ UDP-glucose is the direct glucose donor used by glycogen synthase to extend the glycogen chain during glycogen synthesis.
  • ➤ UDP-glucose
  • ➤ glycogen synthase

questions.text: Which enzyme plays an important role in regulating blood glucose levels after feeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glucokinase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucokinase regulates blood glucose levels after feeding by converting glucose to glucose-6-phosphate in the pancreas and liver.
  • ➤ Glucokinase

questions.text: Under conditions of anaerobic glycolysis, the NAD+ required by glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase is supplied by a reaction catalyzed by which of the following enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lactate dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lactate dehydrogenase regenerates NAD+ in anaerobic glycolysis, allowing glycolysis to continue by providing NAD+ to glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.
  • ➤ Lactate dehydrogenase

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme dysfunction leads to lactic acidosis in thiamine deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pyruvate dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyruvate dehydrogenase dysfunction leads to lactic acidosis in thiamine deficiency because the enzyme requires thiamine as a cofactor to convert pyruvate to acetyl-CoA
  • ➤ Pyruvate dehydrogenase

questions.text: Which of the following represents the enzyme deficiency that leads to “essential fructosuria”?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fructokinase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fructokinase deficiency causes essential fructosuria , a benign condition where fructose is excreted in the urine without causing significant symptoms​
  • ➤ Fructokinase deficiency
  • ➤ essential fructosuria

questions.text: A biochemist was studying the functional groups of carbohydrates. There are groups of carbohydrates based on functional groups. All of the following are examples of aldose sugars except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fructose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fructose is a keto sugar , whereas the others (glyceraldehyde, erythrose, and mannose) are aldose sugars​
  • ➤ keto sugar

questions.text: The man’s brain would attempt to decrease consumption of glucose and increase consumption of ketones in order to protect the breakdown (catabolism) of which one of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Muscle protein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The brain shifts to using ketone bodies during prolonged starvation to preserve muscle protein from catabolism​
  • ➤ ketone bodies
  • ➤ muscle protein

questions.text: Organ which can utilize glucose, fatty acids, and ketone bodies, is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Skeletal Muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Skeletal muscle can utilize glucose, fatty acids, and ketone bodies, especially during starvation.
  • ➤ Skeletal muscle

questions.text: Oligomycins are macrolides created by Streptomyces that can be poisonous to other organisms. An investigator studied the possible mode of action of the oligomycin molecule on experimental rats. The investigator reported the death of rats administered with oligomycin. He found ATP synthesis in rats was inhibited. Select the incorrect statement:

options.label: C
options.text: Reduce electron flow through the electron transport chain

options.label: D
options.text: Has no action on F1 subunit of proton channel

questions.correct_answer: B. Activating proton channel, FO subunit
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Activating proton channel, FO subunit

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oligomycin inhibits ATP synthesis by blocking the FO subunit of ATP synthase, preventing proton flow and halting ATP production.

questions.text: The oxidation of the primary alcohol group in glucose results in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucuronic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oxidation of the primary alcohol group (carbon 6) in glucose leads to the formation of glucuronic acid
  • ➤ primary alcohol group
  • ➤ glucuronic acid

questions.text: Muscle cannot make use of glycogen for energy in the absence of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Phosphorylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Muscle phosphorylase is necessary for glycogen breakdown, and its deficiency leads to McArdle disease , where glycogen cannot be utilized for energy
  • ➤ phosphorylase
  • ➤ McArdle disease

questions.text: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is the endothelial cell-associated enzyme necessary for the release of fatty acids from circulating lipoproteins. Which of the following apolipoproteins is required to activate LPL-mediated release of fatty acids from chylomicrons?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Apo CII

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Apo CII is required to activate lipoprotein lipase (LPL) for the release of fatty acids from chylomicrons
  • ➤ Apo CII

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has been diagnosed with retinitis pigmentosa, peripheral polyneuropathy, and cerebellar ataxia. Analysis of his cerebrospinal fluid indicated a high protein content but no elevation of cell number. A telling clinical finding was a high level of serum phytanic acid. These findings are indicative of which of the following disorders?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Refsum disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Refsum disease results from the accumulation of phytanic acid due to the deficiency of phytonoyl-CoA hydroxylase , and it presents with retinitis pigmentosa, polyneuropathy, and cerebellar ataxia​
  • ➤ Refsum disease
  • ➤ phytonoyl-CoA hydroxylase

questions.text: A young man on examination has been found to have increased serum cholesterol. On further study, only LDL is increased in cholesterol, while the rest of the lipoproteins are normal. His father had a similar history. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TYPE II hyperlipoproteinemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type II hyperlipoproteinemia is caused by a defect in the LDL receptor or apo B100 , leading to isolated LDL cholesterol elevation
  • ➤ Type II hyperlipoproteinemia
  • ➤ LDL receptor
  • ➤ apo B100
  • ➤ LDL cholesterol

questions.text: Presence of ketonuria and absence of glycosuria are the essential clinical manifestations in one of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prolonged starvation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In prolonged starvation , ketonuria is present without glycosuria, as the body breaks down fat for energy
  • ➤ prolonged starvation

questions.text: Which of the following storage disorders is shown in the image given below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Niemann-Pick disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Niemann-Pick disease is characterized by the foamy appearance of cells due to the accumulation of sphingomyelin resulting from sphingomyelinase deficiency.
  • ➤ Niemann-Pick disease

questions.text: Eye change shown in photograph is seen in which Vitamin ……….. Deficiency:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) deficiency leads to circumcorneal vascularization and keratitis along with other characteristic features such as magenta-colored tongue and cheilosis .
  • ➤ Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) deficiency
  • ➤ circumcorneal vascularization
  • ➤ keratitis
  • ➤ magenta-colored tongue
  • ➤ cheilosis

questions.text: Hormone sensitive lipase is not activated by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Insulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase, while glucagon , catecholamines , and T4 activate it, facilitating fat breakdown.
  • ➤ Insulin
  • ➤ glucagon
  • ➤ catecholamines
  • ➤ T4

questions.text: The product of oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Propionyl CoA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Odd-chain fatty acid oxidation results in propionyl CoA , which is further converted to succinyl CoA, distinguishing it from even-chain fatty acid metabolism.
  • ➤ propionyl CoA

questions.text: Ketone body which is maximum in Diabetic ketoacidosis:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Beta hydroxy Butyrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta hydroxy Butyrate is the ketone body found in the highest concentrations during diabetic ketoacidosis due to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio.
  • ➤ Beta hydroxy Butyrate

questions.text: Ketogenesis is a biochemical reaction in which ketone bodies are synthesized in the liver through the degradation of free fatty acids and ketogenic amino acids. Which statement about ketogenesis is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Ketone bodies are utilized by hepatocytes

options.label: B
options.text: Ketogenesis occurs in the mitochondria of hepatocytes

options.label: C
options.text: Ketosis can deplete the alkali reserve

options.label: D
options.text: Ketogenesis is exaggerated in diabetes mellitus and prolonged starvation. It is termed as Ketosis

questions.correct_answer: A. Ketone bodies are utilized by hepatocytes
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ketone bodies are utilized by hepatocytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The liver synthesizes ketone bodies but cannot utilize them because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase . Therefore, the statement that hepatocytes can utilize ketone bodies is false.

questions.text: Male patient of age 18 years reported with symptoms of full body pain, foamy urine, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and rash over skin of extremities, back, and chest. Examination and tests revealed the angiokeratomas, acro-paresthesia, clouding of the corneas without any effect on vision, deficiency of alpha-galactosidase leading to accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. The findings are supplemented with Fig 1 and Fig 2. Diagnose the clinical condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fabry disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fabry disease is a genetic disorder characterized by alpha-galactosidase deficiency leading to globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) accumulation. Key features include neuropathic pain, angiokeratomas, renal dysfunction, and corneal clouding.

questions.text: In comparative sizes of Lipoproteins (photograph), ‘A’ represents:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chylomicrons

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chylomicrons are the largest lipoproteins, transporting dietary triglycerides from the intestines to peripheral tissues.

questions.text: All the statements regarding LDL receptors are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: Present only in the extra-hepatic tissues

options.label: B
options.text: Clathrin-coated pits contain the receptor on the cell membrane

options.label: C
options.text: It is taken into the cells by endocytosis

options.label: D
options.text: Increased cellular cholesterol down-regulates the synthesis of LDL receptors

questions.correct_answer: A. Present only in the extra-hepatic tissues
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Present only in the extra-hepatic tissues

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LDL receptors are present in both hepatic and extra-hepatic tissues, and they play a crucial role in regulating cholesterol levels by mediating the endocytosis of LDL particles.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is not a component of fatty acid synthase complex?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acetyl-CoA carboxylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is a rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid synthesis but is not part of the fatty acid synthase complex .
  • ➤ not part of the fatty acid synthase complex

questions.text: Carboxylation of clotting factors by vitamin K is required to be biologically active. Which of the following amino acid is carboxylated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glutamate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin K-dependent carboxylation is essential for the biological activation of clotting factors through the modification of glutamate residues.
  • ➤ glutamate

questions.text: Parents bring in their 2-week-old child fearful that he has ingested a poison. They had delayed disposing one of the child’s diapers and noted a black discoloration where the urine had collected. Later, they realized that all of the child’s diapers would turn black if stored as waste for a day or so. Knowing that phenol groups can complex to form colors, which amino acid pathways are implicated in this phenomenon?

options.label: A
options.text: The phenylalanine, tyrosine, and homogentisate pathway

options.label: C
options.text: The leucine, isoleucine, and valine pathway

questions.correct_answer: A. The phenylalanine, tyrosine, and homogentisate pathway
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The phenylalanine, tyrosine, and homogentisate pathway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The phenylalanine and tyrosine pathway leads to the production of homogentisate, and its accumulation, due to a deficiency in homogentisate oxidase, causes the black discoloration of urine seen in alkaptonuria .
  • ➤ phenylalanine and tyrosine pathway
  • ➤ alkaptonuria

questions.text: This unique absorption pattern is shown by which analyte?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Porphyrins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sharp absorption around 400 nm is characteristic of porphyrins , specifically associated with the Soret band .
  • ➤ porphyrins
  • ➤ Soret band

questions.text: A girl with a habit of eating paint peeled off from the wall presented with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off with tingling sensation of limbs associated with weakness of the limbs. Which of the enzyme will show reduced activity in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PBG Synthase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lead poisoning inhibits PBG Synthase , leading to neurological and abdominal symptoms due to disrupted heme synthesis.
  • ➤ PBG Synthase

questions.text: There is but a single enzyme-catalyzed reaction in the human body known to generate carbon monoxide (CO) as one of its products. Which of the following enzymes represents the one that catalyzes this CO-producing reaction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Heme oxygenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heme oxygenase is the only enzyme in the human body that generates carbon monoxide (CO) during the breakdown of heme .
  • ➤ Heme oxygenase
  • ➤ carbon monoxide
  • ➤ heme

questions.text: The condition seen in the photograph is due to the deficiency of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin A deficiency is responsible for the development of Bitot's spots , which are foamy patches on the conjunctiva due to keratinization.
  • ➤ Vitamin A deficiency
  • ➤ Bitot's spots

questions.text: An individual harboring a mutation in ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) would be expected to exhibit which of the following measurable abnormalities?

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated urinary excretion of argininosuccinic acid

questions.correct_answer: C. Elevation in blood orotic acid
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Elevation in blood orotic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A mutation in OTC causes an increase in orotic acid levels in the blood due to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which spills into the pyrimidine synthesis pathway.
  • ➤ OTC
  • ➤ orotic acid

questions.text: Which one of the following is optically inactive amino acid that lacks chiral carbon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glycine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycine is the only amino acid without a chiral center, making it optically inactive.
  • ➤ Glycine

questions.text: Sample from the area given in the Image can be used to know?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inborn errors of metabolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The heel prick test is primarily used to screen for inborn errors of metabolism in newborns using techniques like tandem mass spectrometry .
  • ➤ heel prick test
  • ➤ inborn errors of metabolism
  • ➤ tandem mass spectrometry

questions.text: Which product of the citric acid cycle is used for detoxification of ammonia in the brain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alphaketoglutarate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alphaketoglutarate is the key intermediate from the citric acid cycle that is utilized in the brain for ammonia detoxification, forming glutamate and glutamine.
  • ➤ Alphaketoglutarate

questions.text: Amino acids secreted in cystinuria are all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Histidine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ In cystinuria , the amino acids Cystine, Ornithine, Lysine , and Arginine are excreted in the urine, but Histidine is not involved.
  • ➤ cystinuria
  • ➤ Cystine, Ornithine, Lysine
  • ➤ Arginine
  • ➤ Histidine

questions.text: Which one of the following amino acids is most likely to be found in the transmembrane region of a protein?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Leucine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The transmembrane regions of proteins typically contain non-polar amino acids like leucine , which interact favorably with the lipid bilayer.
  • ➤ non-polar amino acids
  • ➤ leucine

questions.text: The production of mRNA in eukaryotic cells requires a large number of steps, and drugs targeted to any of these steps could block mRNA production. Which one of the following accurately describes a part of the process of producing mRNA from a eukaryotic gene?

options.label: A
options.text: The sense strand of DNA is the strand used by RNA polymerase during transcription

options.label: B
options.text: The antisense DNA strand is identical to the RNA transcript except that the DNA strand contains thymine and the RNA strand contains uracil.

options.label: C
options.text: The first RNA form produced contains both intron and exon sequences

options.label: D
options.text: Mature mRNA contains a cap at the 5′-end, a poly (A) tail at the 3′ end, introns, and exons.

questions.correct_answer: C. The first RNA form produced contains both intron and exon sequences
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The first RNA form produced contains both intron and exon sequences

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first RNA form produced in eukaryotes contains both introns and exons , and is known as heteronuclear RNA (hnRNA) .
  • ➤ introns
  • ➤ exons
  • ➤ heteronuclear RNA (hnRNA)

questions.text: The rate of DNA synthesis in a culture of cells could be most accurately determined by measuring the incorporation of which of the following radioactive compounds?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thymidine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thymidine is used as a specific marker for DNA synthesis because it is unique to DNA, making it the most accurate compound to measure for this purpose.
  • ➤ DNA synthesis

questions.text: The protein rich in basic amino acids, which functions in the packaging of DNA in chromosomes, is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Histone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histones are rich in lysine and arginine , allowing them to bind to DNA and facilitate its packaging into chromosomes.
  • ➤ Histones
  • ➤ lysine
  • ➤ arginine

questions.text: The gaps between segments of DNA on the lagging strand produced by restriction enzymes are rejoined/sealed by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) DNA Ligases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DNA Ligases are essential for sealing the gaps between DNA fragments, particularly on the lagging strand during replication.
  • ➤ DNA Ligases

questions.text: If a 4-nucleotide sequence codes for an amino acid instead of 3, then theoretically how many unique amino acids could be coded by such a system?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 256

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 4-nucleotide codon system would produce 256 possible codons , leading to the encoding of a much larger number of amino acids compared to the standard 64 codons in the current 3-nucleotide system.
  • ➤ 256 possible codons

questions.text: Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) is characterized by a complete lack of cell-mediated and humoral immunity. This disorder results from a deficiency in which of the following enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adenosine deaminase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SCID results from a deficiency in adenosine deaminase (ADA) , leading to a severe defect in both cellular and humoral immunity.
  • ➤ SCID
  • ➤ adenosine deaminase (ADA)

questions.text: The bacterial lac operon is controlled by both glucose and lactose levels. Which of the following conditions would result in the greatest level of transcription from the lac operon?
questions.correct_answer: C. Lactose present but no glucose
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lactose present but no glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The greatest level of transcription of the lac operon occurs when lactose is present and glucose is absent .
  • ➤ greatest level of transcription
  • ➤ lac operon
  • ➤ lactose is present and glucose is absent

questions.text: Steroids act via nuclear receptors which interact with DNA through:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zinc finger motif

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Steroid receptors bind to DNA via a zinc finger motif , allowing them to regulate gene transcription.
  • ➤ zinc finger motif

questions.text: True about Sickle cell disease are all, except:

options.label: A
options.text: Single nucleotide change results in change of Glutamate to Valine

options.label: B
options.text: Sticky patch is generated as a result of replacement of a non-polar residue with a polar residue

options.label: C
options.text: HbS confers resistance against malaria in heterozygotes

options.label: D
options.text: RFLP results from a single base change

questions.correct_answer: B. Sticky patch is generated as a result of replacement of a non-polar residue with a polar residue
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sticky patch is generated as a result of replacement of a non-polar residue with a polar residue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sickle cell disease results from a single nucleotide change that replaces glutamate with valine, creating abnormal hemoglobin and sickle-shaped red blood cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for protein synthesis in eukaryotes:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) RNA Polymerase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RNA Polymerase is not required for translation, but ribosomes, peptidyl transferase, and amino acyl tRNA synthetase are crucial for protein synthesis in eukaryotes.
  • ➤ RNA Polymerase

questions.text: Inhibitor A and B are:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Uncompetitive and non-competitive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Lineweaver-Burk plots are vital tools for identifying the mechanism of enzyme inhibitors, with uncompetitive inhibitors affecting both Km and Vmax (parallel line shift) and non-competitive inhibitors impacting Vmax only (vertical shift).

questions.text: Lactate dehydrogenase is an enzyme found in nearly all living cells. LDH catalyzes the conversion of lactate to pyruvate and back, as it converts NAD+ to NADH and back. What is the best-suited statement for isoenzyme?

options.label: C
options.text: Multimeric enzymes with different subunit composition, different electrophoretic properties but similar functions

questions.correct_answer: C. Multimeric enzymes with different subunit composition, different electrophoretic properties but similar functions
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Multimeric enzymes with different subunit composition, different electrophoretic properties but similar functions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Isoenzymes are multimeric enzymes with different subunit compositions and electrophoretic properties, but they perform similar functions.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding oxygenases except:
questions.correct_answer: D. Required for carboxylation of drugs
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Required for carboxylation of drugs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oxygenases are enzymes that incorporate oxygen atoms into substrates, but they are not involved in the carboxylation of drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following plays a role in the hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ascorbic Acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ascorbic acid is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in collagen synthesis, which is a critical process for maintaining connective tissue strength and integrity.
  • ➤ Ascorbic acid

questions.text: A 56-year-old homeless man presents to ER with increased fatigability and exertional dyspnea. Physical examination shows significant lower extremity edema and decreased sensation over the ankles and feet. Further evaluation reveals cardiac dilation and increased cardiac output. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thiamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiamine deficiency leads to wet beriberi , which presents with symptoms of heart failure, including cardiac dilation , lower extremity edema , and increased cardiac output .
  • ➤ Thiamine deficiency
  • ➤ wet beriberi
  • ➤ cardiac dilation
  • ➤ lower extremity edema
  • ➤ increased cardiac output

questions.text: Vitamin which is excreted in urine is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin and is excreted in urine when present in excess.
  • ➤ Vitamin C

questions.text: Zinc is a cofactor for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Alcohol dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zinc is a cofactor for alcohol dehydrogenase and plays a crucial role in the enzyme's ability to metabolize alcohol.
  • ➤ Zinc
  • ➤ alcohol dehydrogenase

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 → A, 2 → C, 3 → B, 4 → D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Each glycogen storage disorder has specific clinical features tied to the enzyme deficiency and the resulting accumulation of glycogen or its intermediates.

questions.text: Muscle is not involved in which type of glycogen storage disease:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Type I

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type I glycogen storage disease (Von Gierke's disease) does not affect muscle tissue because the deficient enzyme, glucose-6-phosphatase , is absent from muscles.
  • ➤ Type I glycogen storage disease (Von Gierke's disease)
  • ➤ glucose-6-phosphatase

questions.text: A patient presents with hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly. Hypoglycemia does not respond to glucagon. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Von Gierke’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Von Gierke's disease causes severe hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly, and the hypoglycemia does not respond to glucagon due to the lack of glucose-6-phosphatase.
  • ➤ Von Gierke's disease

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is common for both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glucose-6-phosphatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphatase is an enzyme that is critical for both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, as it helps release glucose into the bloodstream during periods of fasting.
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphatase

questions.text: A child presents with hepatomegaly and bilateral lenticular opacities. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes will not cause such features?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lactase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lactase deficiency causes gastrointestinal symptoms, but does not lead to hepatomegaly or bilateral lenticular opacities .
  • ➤ Lactase deficiency
  • ➤ hepatomegaly
  • ➤ bilateral lenticular opacities

questions.text: Anticoagulant used to estimate glucose from a sample sent from PHC is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Potassium oxalate + NaF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For glucose estimation, Potassium oxalate combined with Sodium fluoride (NaF) is the appropriate anticoagulant to prevent glycolysis and ensure accurate measurement.
  • ➤ Potassium oxalate
  • ➤ Sodium fluoride (NaF)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amino acid-derived neurotransmitter?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Creatine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Creatine is not an amino acid-derived neurotransmitter, but rather a compound involved in energy metabolism.
  • ➤ Creatine

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with post-transcription modification?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glycosylation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycosylation is a post-translational modification and is not involved in post-transcriptional processes such as methylation, capping, and endonuclease cleavage.
  • ➤ Glycosylation

questions.text: Fluorescence means:

options.label: B
options.text: Release of longer wavelength light on absorbing light of shorter wavelength

options.label: C
options.text: Release of shorter wavelength light on absorbing light of longer wavelength

options.label: D
options.text: Release of equal wavelength light at constant rate

questions.correct_answer: B. Release of longer wavelength light on absorbing light of shorter wavelength
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Release of longer wavelength light on absorbing light of shorter wavelength

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluorescence is the emission of light with a longer wavelength after absorbing light of a shorter wavelength .
  • ➤ longer wavelength
  • ➤ shorter wavelength

questions.text: A scientist is investigating Chronic Myeloid Leukaemia (CML). He develops a fluorescent DNA probe to bind to the BCR-ABL fusion gene for direct visualisation of Philadelphia translocation. Which molecular technique is he using?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fluorescence In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FISH is the preferred technique for visualising chromosomal translocations, such as the Philadelphia translocation, using fluorescent DNA probes.
  • ➤ FISH

questions.text: Rapid method of chromosome identification in interphase is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FISH is the rapid method used for chromosome identification in interphase cells, allowing for faster results compared to traditional karyotyping methods.
  • ➤ FISH
  • ➤ This format now follows the exact style and instructions you requested. Please let me know if you'd like me to proceed with more questions in the same manner.

questions.text: Korsakoff psychosis true except? Amnesia Confabulation Ophthalmoplegia Ataxia
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Korsakoff psychosis is marked by amnesia and confabulation , while ophthalmoplegia and ataxia are features of Wernicke's encephalopathy.
  • ➤ amnesia
  • ➤ confabulation
  • ➤ ophthalmoplegia
  • ➤ ataxia

questions.text: A patient presented with a bacterial infection that produced an endotoxin that inhibits PEPCK. In this patient, then, under these conditions, glucose production from which one of the following precursors would be inhibited?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose production from alanine is inhibited when PEPCK is blocked, as it requires the conversion of pyruvate to PEP.
  • ➤ alanine

questions.text: Pyruvate can be converted directly to all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyruvate can be directly converted to alanine, acetyl CoA, and lactate but not directly to PEP, which requires an additional step involving oxaloacetate.

questions.text: An adolescent female develops hemiballismus after anesthesia for a routine operation. She is tall and lanky, and it is noted that she and her sister both had previous operations for dislocated lenses of the eyes. The symptoms are suspicious for the disease homocystinuria. Which of the following statements is descriptive of this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Patients may be treated with dietary supplements of vitamin B12

options.label: B
options.text: Patients may be treated with dietary supplements of vitamin C

options.label: C
options.text: There is deficient excretion of homocysteine

options.label: D
options.text: There is a defect in the ability to form cystathionine from homocysteine and serine

questions.correct_answer: D. There is a defect in the ability to form cystathionine from homocysteine and serine
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Homocystinuria is characterized by a defect in the enzyme cystathionine beta-synthase , which prevents the conversion of homocysteine to cystathionine.
  • ➤ cystathionine beta-synthase

questions.text: In folate deficiency the False statement is?

options.label: A
options.text: High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid

options.label: C
options.text: B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate

options.label: D
options.text: Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected

questions.correct_answer: B. Hemolytic anemia is a feature
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In folate deficiency, the characteristic anemia is megaloblastic , not hemolytic , and purine and pyrimidine synthesis is disrupted.
  • ➤ megaloblastic
  • ➤ hemolytic

questions.text: Excessive ultraviolet (UV) radiation is harmful to life. The damage caused to the biological systems by ultraviolet radiation is by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary damage caused by UV radiation to biological systems is the formation of thymidine dimers in DNA
  • ➤ formation of thymidine dimers

questions.text: In the given image, a child develops blisters on exposure to sunlight. Irregular dark spots on the skin are also found. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is defective?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A defect in the nucleotide excision repair pathway leads to conditions like xeroderma pigmentosum, where patients are unable to repair UV-induced DNA damage, causing blisters and hyperpigmentation after sun exposure.
  • ➤ nucleotide excision repair

questions.text: During the process of protein synthesis, the factor eEF-2 induces the hydrolysis of GTP. The energy of this hydrolysis is coupled to which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Amino acid activation by attachment to a tRNA

options.label: B
options.text: Correct alignment of the mRNA on the 40S ribosome

questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hydrolysis of GTP by eEF-2 is essential for the translocation of the ribosome during the elongation phase of protein synthesis​
  • ➤ eEF-2
  • ➤ translocation of the ribosome
